title: 109_hr5939
content: The "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" may be cited as the short title. This Act includes provisions related to terrorist offenses resulting in death. SEC. 2 of the "Criminal Terrorism Improvements Act of 2006" introduces a new offense, "Terrorist offenses resulting in death," under Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code. It states that anyone who, in the course of committing a terrorist offense, causes the death of a person, shall be punished by death or imprisonment for any term of years or for life. The term "terrorist offense" is defined as a felony offense that is a Federal crime of terrorism or an offense under specific sections of the law. SEC. 3 introduces the death penalty for certain terror-related crimes, including threats involving nuclear weapons, missile systems, atomic weapons, radiological dispersal devices, and the variola virus. SEC. 4 increases penalties for these offenses. SEC. 4 increases penalties for certain offenses under title 18, United States Code, including increasing the maximum sentence from 20 years to 30 years for Section 2332(b)(1) and from 10 years to 20 years for Section 2332(c). It also amends Section 2339C(d) to increase penalties to 30 years for paragraph (1) and 20 years for paragraph (2). SEC. 6 amends penalties for providing material support to terrorist groups and receiving military-type training from a foreign terrorist organization. It increases the minimum sentence to 10 years or life imprisonment, and if death results, the minimum sentence is 30 years or life. SEC. 7 denies federal benefits to convicted terrorists. SEC. 7 amends Chapter 113B of title 18, United States Code to deny Federal benefits to individuals convicted of Federal crimes of terrorism. It defines 'Federal benefit' and specifies the ineligibility for such benefits as determined by the court. Section 2339D of title 18, United States Code, amended to include attempts or conspiracies to receive, after receives.
